author-notes.corresp: Xing-Song Wang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Southeast University, Jiangsu, Nanjing 211189, China. Email: xswang@seu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Given that thermal errors in a crank press can critically reduce machine accuracy, the current study proposes the use of the dynamic thermal error dimension chain method to analyze the thermal errors of the crank press. The thermal error of the complete machine is also determined by the thermal errors of the total components, and the dynamic error dimension chain allows the examination of the relationship between the total thermal error of the crank press and the respective errors of the primary components, such as the frame, crank, connecting rod, and slider. In addition, a finite element method model was developed to predict the temperature distribution change and thermally induced machine tool errors of a crank press. The experiments were conducted on a crank press to verify both the position of the slider running at the bottom dead center and temperature changes at various critical points in the press. The temperature of the respective components rose, resulting in different components affecting the machine tool thermal error at different times.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Crank presses have been widely used in industrial manufacturing because of several advantages, such as high productivity, high accuracy, and excellent mechanical properties. With the improvement in industrial and mechanical technology, a higher level of machine tool accuracy of crank presses is required to ensure the machining precision and quality of each work piece. The work piece accuracy was affected by numerous factors, such as the control of the total machining process, surfaces of the die cavity, and press deflection characteristics.1 A crank press drives the slider-crank mechanism, forming the work piece with the die repeatedly running at bottom dead center (BDC). Therefore, the position error of the machine, relative to BDC, directly determines the work piece accuracy. Error resources include geometric errors inherent to the machine itself, elastic errors induced by force application, clearance errors at linkage joints, surface errors of the die cavity, and thermal errors resulting from temperature change. Among these errors, the focus of the current research is on how thermal errors affect machine tool accuracy.

A large number of recent studies have investigated thermal errors existing in various machine tools and have been seeking ways to reduce these errors.2 Zhao et al.3 investigated the thermal behavior of a computer numerically controlled (CNC) machine tool spindle using the finite element method (FEM) and optimized the thermal key points to build the thermal error model, as validated by the subsequent experiment. Rakuff and Beaudet4 measured and modeled environmental temperature variation errors and studied the thermal effects and deflections of the structural loop of the diamond turning of rotationally symmetric structured surfaces. Using FEM simulation and experiments, Creighton et al.5 studied the temperature changes and structural deformation of a high-speed micro-milling spindle, subsequently developing a displacement model and compensation scheme to reduce the thermal errors. Tang and Sasahara6 proposed a FEM model to investigate the temperature rise and the thermal expansion of the cylinder liner during the boring process. They also analyzed the effects of various cutting conditions, such as cutting force, cutting speed, and air cooling. Kang et al.7 presented a dynamic neural network model to predict thermal deformation in machine tools. They obtained the relationship between input and output data with different sampling intervals. They also performed the experiments to validate the model. Zhu et al.8 proposed the thermal mode analysis to build robust thermal error models of machine tools by calculating the dominant thermal modes. The authors also analyzed the position independent and position dependent thermal errors through both simulation and experiments.

Krulewich9 introduced the use of the Gaussian integration technique on a thermal error model. He set up a position-dependent thermal error model to predict thermally induced errors based on measured temperatures. He then conducted experiments on a spindle under different conditions, which resulted in a 93%–96% thermal error prediction. Bossmanns et al.10,11 developed a finite difference thermal model to measure the power distribution of a high-speed motorized spindle in end milling, after which the major heat sources and sinks were also calculated. The performed model validations included steady state, transient state, and power balance analysis. According to Ramesh et al.,12 –14 operating parameters have significant effects on the positioning error of machine tools. They then conducted several experiments on a three-axis vertical machining center to measure the temperature and positioning error, after which they described, based on these experiments, the effect of operating parameters on the axis positioning error.

The aforementioned studies revealed the characteristics of temperature distribution and thermal errors in various machine tools, thus improving the working accuracy of these machines. However, these studies primarily focused on the thermal deformation of the spindles, rather than the complete machines.

Yun et al.15 studied the thermal deformation of high-speed feed drive systems, including the ball screw and the guide way. They performed simulations and experiments to analyze the linear positioning error of the ball screw and the thermal deformation of the guide. The thermal error of the machine tool was found to be proportionally rooted to the guide way and the ball screw. Chen16 established a measurement system to calibrate the thermal errors of a vertical machining center. The author considered the thermal error of the machine tool, including spindle growth, cantilever-arm bending, z-axis expansion, column bending, y-axis expansion, and x-axis expansion. The author also established the calibrations of these thermal error compositions.

Pereira et al.17 employed the homogeneous transformation matrices to model the total error of a CNC grinding machine while considering individual error components. The total error was negative at the beginning of the simulation, but the trend reversed after the warm-up cycle. A similar trend of thermal error reversal occurred in the current study.

In previous studies,15 –17 aside from the thermal effect of the spindle, other components of the machine tools have been analyzed. However, the variation in the relationship between the total error and the individual errors has not been fully explained, thus requiring further studies.

Studies have investigated the temperature distribution and thermal errors of various machine tools, such as CNC turning, diamond turning, micro-milling, and grinding. However, few articles have dealt with this kind of research on the crank press. Metal-cutting machine tool process work pieces are used to obtain potential components through the continuous high-speed relative motion of the cutting tool and the work piece, one of which is mounted directly on the rotating spindle. In contrast, the crank press drives the slider-crank mechanism to punch the material when the slider runs at BDC. Therefore, more attention should be focused on the complex dynamic and thermal behavior of the crank press.

In the current article, the dynamic thermal error dimension chain method is proposed to study the variation in the relationship between the total thermal error and the individual thermal errors of the press. The thermal expansions of the complete machine and the primary components are analyzed by calculating the temperature field and thermal deformations of the press. Finally, the effectiveness of approach is validated through a FEM simulation and experiment.

sec.title: The thermal error of the press
Structure and working accuracy of the crank press
sec.p: A crank press typically comprises a base, frame, motor, and slider-crank mechanism (Figure 1). The motor provides the main power to drive the crankshaft and the connecting rod, and the slider then punches the work pieces (Figure 2).

A number of factors affect the work piece accuracy, such as the surfaces of the die cavity, and the press deflection characteristics. The stamping parts are formed directly in the die cavity, and the accuracy is determined basically by the mold and die. The press shut height, defined as the distance between the bottom surface of the slider and top surface of the work table, is equal to the die shut height, defined as the distance between the top surface of upper die and bottom surface of lower die, when the press is running at BDC. Thus, the press deflection will also affect the precision of the work piece by changing the die shut height.

The crank press supports the working load, gravity, and inertia of the moving parts under different operating conditions. The forces produce not only elastic distortion, but also frictional heat, resulting in the temperature change and the thermal deformation of the components. Finally, these factors result in the deflection of the press, which consequently affects the work pieces.

The current article primarily focuses on the thermal error of the press. The thermal error of the press at BDC is determined by all the thermal errors of the press components. The current study proposes the dynamic thermal error dimension chain method to study the relationship between the thermal error variation of BDC and the thermal error variations of all components.

A finite element analysis of the crank press was conducted to obtain an approximate temperature distribution and the corresponding structural deformation in the slider-crank. The FEM of the crank press machine was established using ANSYS V12 (Figure 4). With three-dimensional (3D) coupled-field solid (SOLID5), the model was meshed into 71,644 hexagonal elements, and this mesh level resulted in a good tradeoff between simulation accuracy and solution time.

sec.title: The thermal boundary condition
sec.p: When the press runs, frictional heat generated during the movement of the slider-crank mechanism leads to an uneven temperature distribution in the machine. In turn, this causes the position of the slider at BDC to drift away from the initial state. Therefore, to predict and analyze the temperature distribution and thermal deformation, the thermal boundary conditions are calculated first. In this section, the kinematic and kinetic parameters of the movement of press is first analyzed, and then the thermal boundary conditions of the press, including heat sources and coefficients of heat convection, are calculated.

sec.title: The power of heat sources
sec.p: The thermally induced errors are caused by the heat flow from internal and external sources, as well as the environmental temperature. In the crank press, the major heat sources are internal, which include the ball bearings, sliding rails, spherical hinge, and motor.

A total of six rolling bearings were mounted on the crankshaft (Figure 3). A pair of spherical roller bearings (22,312 K) was used to mount the rotor system on the frame, and several spherical ball bearings (2218) were employed to link the crankshaft and the connecting rod. Meanwhile, the deep groove ball bearings (3211) were installed on the crankshaft to support the flywheel. The bearings in the slider-crank bore the forces from the moving components, whereas the bearings (3211) bore the gravity of the flywheel.

This kind of convection form is called forced convection. When the crank press stops, the convection form turns into the natural convection, and the coefficient of convection heat transfer is assumed to be 10 W/(m2k) based on practical experiences.3

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Based on the parameters of the slider-crank mechanism (Table 1), the thermal boundary conditions were calculated when the rotation speed was 250 r/min. The ambient temperature was set as 14 °C because the experiments were conducted at approximately the same initial temperature. The material of the driving shaft, flywheel, connecting rod, and rolling bearing were 40 Cr, QT600-3, HT200, and GCr15, respectively, and those of both the slider and frame were HT300. The properties of the aforementioned materials are shown in Table 2.

The connecting rod forces in the slider-crank were calculated when the mechanisms run in the idle state. The dynamic responses of the shaft in various conditions were also obtained. Based on the motion parameters of the mechanism, the heating value and convection heat transfer coefficient were calculated3 and subsequently applied to the simulation of the FEM model of the press.

sec.title: Simulation of the press temperature field
sec.p: The temperature field of the mechanism was calculated using the FEM analysis (Figure 5). The simulated temperature curve of the test points on the crank press is shown in Figure 6. The equilibrium temperature of the two test points in the connecting rod was the highest, and the left and right shaft blocks possessed the second highest temperature. Other test points possessed similar temperatures, which were the lowest. In approximately the first hour after operation, the temperature increased rapidly and then balanced out gradually. The temperature field was analyzed in detail and compared with the experimental data in ‘Temperature field experiment’.

Given the analysis above, although all components extended through thermal expansion, some were increasing loops, whereas others were decreasing loops. These components affected the variation direction of the complete machine differently. Moreover, the press is mainly comprised of frame, shaft, connecting rod and slider, and their volumes are different, therefore the temperatures of the components increased at different rates, which resulted in thermal expansion at different scales. The direction of the thermal error of the complete machine drifted, depending on whether increasing loops or decreasing loops had greater variation value.

Furthermore, when the variation value of increasing loops equaled that of decreasing loops, the thermal error of the complete machine was zero. This principle provided the basis for design optimization and error compensation.

sec.title: Experiment
sec.p: The thermal error measurement experiment was designed to measure the temperature and thermal deformation of the press. The experiment primarily comprised the thermocouple, eddy current sensor, and data acquisition system.

Omega solder-joint K thermocouple wire was used to measure the temperature of the selected measuring points of both the high-speed press and the ambient temperature. The major heat sources included bearings, the spherical hinge, guide rails, and the motor. In addition, the temperature variation of the connecting rod, slider, and frame directly resulted in thermal expansion. Therefore, the temperature measuring points were selected in the vicinity of these components, as shown in Figure 9(a).

caption.p: The temperature and thermal error measurement. (a) Temperature measuring points of the press. (b) BDC displacement measurement.

sec.p: The eddy current sensor was fixed on the supporter and mounted on the work table (Figure 9(b)) to measure the dynamic precision of the press. The lower surface of the slider was detected by the sensor to obtain the thermal error of the press shut height.

sec.title: Temperature field experiment
sec.p: Figure 10 shows the temperature variation curves of the simulation and experiment conducted on each measuring point of the press. Figure 10(a) and (b) show the temperature variation curves of the upper and lower parts of the connecting rod, respectively. The measuring point on the upper part was closer to the connecting rod and rolling bearings 3 and 4. Therefore, the temperature measured at this point rose rapidly, reaching a maximum of 30.5 °C. Meanwhile, the measuring point on the lower part was closer to the connecting rod and the spherical hinge of slider. Therefore, the temperature measured at this point also rose rapidly, reaching a maximum of 29 °C.

caption.p: Temperatures of the measuring points: (a) at the upper part of the connecting rod; (b) at the lower part of the connecting rod; (c) near the motor; (d) at the left bearing seat; (e) at the right bearing seat; (f) at the frame; (g) at the slider; (h) near the left guide rail; (i) near the right guide rail.

sec.p: Figure 10(c) shows the temperature variation curve of the measuring point near the motor. This point was set on the frame as close to the motor as possible. Therefore, this measuring point could reflect the temperature variation in the vicinity of the motor. The balance temperature was 20.5 °C. Figure 10(d) and (e) shows the temperature variation curves of the left and right bearing seats, respectively. The two measuring points were arranged on the left and right bearing seats, and were closer to the rolling bearing of the crankshaft. The balance temperatures for the measuring points on the left and right bearing seats were 25 °C and 24 °C, respectively.

Figure 10(f) shows the temperature variation curve of the measuring point at the frame, the balance temperature of which was 21 °C. Figure 10(g) shows the temperature variation curve of the measuring point at the slider, which was closer to the connecting rod and the spherical hinge of the slider. The average temperature was also 21 °C. Figure 10(h) and (i) shows the temperature variation curves of the measuring points near the left and right guide rails, respectively. The balance temperatures of the measuring points near the left and right guide rails were 20.5 °C and 21 °C, respectively.

The change in temperature field of the press depends on both the machine structure and heat generation from friction. The temperatures of parts rise faster in the early stage, then the rise speeds become slower gradually, and the temperature tends to balance. The rates of temperature change are different owing to the difference in volumes of components.

sec.p: Figures 11(a) and (b) show the thermal error variation curves of the BDC in the simulation and experiment, respectively. During the first 60 min, the displacement of BDC drifted downward to approximately 50 μm, as shown in Figure 11(a). The displacement of BDC thereafter drifted upward to approximately 20 μm away from the turning point.

sec.p: The above analysis showed that the computational value had some deviation from the experimental value. The primary reasons were as follows.

list-item.p: Rotational pair clearance was omitted in the computation of kinematic parameters of the press.
Errors were introduced because of the simplification of the analytical and computational mode of heat source and heat transfer coefficients.
The dynamic thermal error in the horizontal direction was disregarded.
The elastic deformation of the press was neglected.

sec.p: Despite the deviation, the experimental results correlated with the computational results, thereby verifying the accuracy of the 3D FEM established in the current article.

sec.title: Influence of the rotational speed of crankshaft on the dynamic error of press
sec.p: The increase in temperature resulted in the thermal expansion of the components, which, in turn, yielded a working position error of the press. In addition, the rotor speed affected the load on the rolling bearing, as well as the friction of heat sources. These factors resulted in increasing temperatures at different rates, consequently affecting the variation rate of the working error.

Figure 12 shows the thermal error curves at different rotational speeds. When the rotational speed levels were 100, 150, 200, and 250 r/min, the downward errors of the left BDC were 8, 14, 24, and 50 μm, respectively, and the upward errors were 9, 10, 7, and 31 μm, respectively. Moreover, the downward errors of the right BDC at the four given rotational speed levels were 8, 9, 18, and 47 μm, respectively, and the upward displacement errors were 14, 17, 11, and 39 μm, respectively. Although the speed varied, thermal error variation curves followed similar trends. In addition, when the rotational speed of the press increased, the variation amplitude errors of the BDC increased correspondingly in both downward and upward stages.

The loads on rolling bearings 1 and 2 differed because the flywheel was mounted on the right end of the crankshaft, which resulted in different heat transfer rates of the heat source. As a consequence, a difference exists in the local temperature variation and thermal expansion of the crankshaft, frame, connecting rod, and slider. This condition ultimately resulted in a higher position of the right side of the BDC (near the flywheel).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the current study, an FEM was established for the thermal analysis of the press. The temperature field and thermal deformation of the press were simulated, and the dynamic dimensional chain method was proposed to examine thermal error. The relationship between the thermal error of primary components and that of the complete machine was analyzed. Thermal error measurement experiments were conducted to verify the accuracy of the FEM. The following conclusions have been obtained.

list-item.p: When the machine tool was in an idle state (250 r/min), the rate of temperature rise in the connecting rod was the fastest, followed by that of the bearing seat in the frame, and then the guide rail. The amounts of temperature rise for the connecting rod, the bearing seat in the frame, and the guide rail were 20, 12, and 8 °C, respectively.
The thermal error of the complete machine was also determined by the thermal errors of various components, among which the frame and connecting rod were major influencing factors.
The working speed of the press directly determined the magnitude of the heat generation rate of the heat source, as well as affected the temperature rise and thermal deformation of the press.

sec.p: In the current study, the dynamic thermal error dimensional chain method was proposed to analyze the crank press. The press had no function for the motion control of numerically controlled machine tools. However, thermal errors could be mitigated by adjusting the temperature of the crucial parts. A thermal error compensating system for the press can subsequently be designed. The method could also be applied to the thermal error analysis of other types of machine tools or mechanisms.
